adjective.description: Chiefly Medicine. Designating an exciting, remote, or occasional cause; specifically designating a cause (usually external) which brings about disease in a predisposed patient. Compare proegumenal. Now historical.
Generally. Designating a primary or initial cause or factor.

origin: Early 17th century; earliest use found in Philemon Holland (1552–1637), translator. From post-classical Latin procatarcticus or its etymon Hellenistic Greek προκαταρκτικός initial, predisposing, also προκαταρκτικά (use as noun of neuter plural) immediate exciting causes of things from ancient Greek προ- + Hellenistic Greek καταρκτικός forming the beginning, after Hellenistic Greek προκατάρχειν to begin first.
